review: Este libro es bastante interesante, se aprecia la visión de la ciencia, lo que es aprender, cómo es que alguien como Poincaré pensaba en todo esto. algo que me parece en particular valioso es que a pesar de ser ensayos donde reflejan lo que muchas personas dedicadas a la ciencia piensan, me parece esto le da un carácter más universal.Además leerlo es muy divertido, se lee fácil, lo recomiendo mucho.

We are in 1905, Poincaré just synthesized the value of science in one stunning sentence "If nature were not beautiful, it would not be worth knowing, and if nature were not worth knowing, life would not be worth living". Priceless! And there is much more. He was following closely the recent developments in both mathematics and physics. Even stating that mechanics was approaching a revolution. Quite right, theory of relativity was published in 1916. He also listed the difficulties of Hilbert-Russell-Whitehead trying to put mathematics on solid foundations. A "fruitless" effort that converged to Gödel's incompleteness theorems in 1931. Astronomy is also discussed. This book is long but Poincaré is sharp and warmth, you may even have goosebumps sometimes.

Libro de ensayo en que analiza la relación entre la ciencia y la realidad con especial énfasis en las matemáticas y sus abstracciones. Además analiza el estado de la física a finales del Siglo XIX y la crisis que intuye que se va a venir.Como documento histórico es muy interesante aunque tiene alguna parte bastante arida. No obstante, es muy interesante ver cómo su punto de vista se relaciona con las teorías que vinieron después.Como libro de divulgación científica esta obviamente desactualizado (tiene más de 100 años) y algunos conceptos que explica están totalmente descartados (es tierno ver su insistencia con el éter). El libro está en un formato deliciosamente pequeño (parecido a las biblias de mano de las películas) y eso siempre suma. Además tiene una foto en portada que es la quintaesencia del señor científico del siglo XIX.Por último, es el primer libro que saco de la biblioteca pública en años. Id a vuestras bibliotecas que son lugares mágicos.

Do not really know how to rate it as I skipped a few chapters. Was definitely not an easy read. I enjoyed many pages reading about Poincaré thoughts on mathematical and physical stuff and getting to know his way of thinking and reasoning. Yet, I would not regard it as one of my favourite books this year.
"We must suffer, we must work, we must pay for our place at the game, but this is for seeing's sake; or at the very least that others may one day see."

Poincare in the characteristic style of French philosophers of the late 19th century, deals with questions ranging from does the scientist create science, the relation of laws and principles, the nuances of an objective reality, the permanence of physical laws amongst other things. He keeps the prose toned up with rigor trying to project a strong & concrete opinion, devoid of equivocation and over-generality as would be the norm for most books on the value of science."Thought is only a gleam in the midst of a long night. But it is this gleam which is everything."
O pensamento não é mais que um clarão em meio a uma longa noite. Mas esse clarão é tudo.

Impulse acquisition at Borders, 2008-04-08; contains Science and Hypothesis (1903), The Value of Science (1905) and Science and Method (1908).A solid read, but dry, oh so very dry! While the exposition is illustrious, a masterful treatment by one of the last great polymaths, swaddled in Parisian eloquence and more gratuitous use of the word "rigour" than I'd known or hoped possible (my favorite: "In all rigour", as in "In all honesty" or "To cut to the chase", a definite addition to the vox dank), it was all written about a semilustrum too early. Poincaré would of course lead the charge on special relativity, and there's sections in here (especially following the early sections on spacetime, which read like a perverse Six Aborted Pieces of Feynman) where you're held captive, waiting for the Lorentz transform to pop out and do its dirty work...then the Modern Science Library's selection of essays pinches off the corpus spongiosum. For $27 at Border's, I expect more than a Unit-pinching.
